subject: Re: How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: ... If you re using JUnit, you can use Jester and a code coverage tool like Clover to give you feedback on what s not being tested, and what s not being tested
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, santhu ps <sps19742001@y...> wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> With respect to the question 'How to write
> effective
> tests".I want to point out one related question
> also that "How we will conclude that the test cases
> that we designed is suficient".

If you're using JUnit, you can use Jester and a code coverage tool
like Clover to give you feedback on what's not being tested, and
what's not being tested precisely enough.

> Effectiveness and sufficiency of test cases what we
> designed can ensure that only if we are designing the
> test cases in a formal methodological manner.

Sorry, I don't buy that. I can see how you'd think that if you
view/practice software development as an engineering activity. I
don't.

That's also not very agile.

- Do TDD
- Come up with a list of tests that nail down the behaviour you need
to implement.
- Write each test, then the code to pass it... one test at a time.
- run a coverage tool against the running of your test suite to find
holes in your test coverage.
- fill in those holes as desired (do you really need to test
toString().. maybe.. maybe not)
- run Jester to see if you have some sloppy tests (or redundant code)
- fix as required.

Better to do it & measure the results than to try & figure it all out
ahead of time.

Dave
